number of helpful: 467 of 513 people (91%) found this review helpful316 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												'Do you recommend this game,' Steam asks me. I do, emphatically. I hope this anecdote from an in-game multiplayer experience I had will explain why. Prepare yourself for ARMA2: The Review: The Movie.Spring, 2011; early in my ARMA career, first tour of duty after a Steam Sale. I'm a fairly fresh recruit, seasoned with a couple dozen game-hours spent trudging through an expansive and swampy learning curve. Spent today at work, drove home, made dinner, cleaned up; it's Game-O'clock. Steam. ARMA2. Launch. Menu surfing, looking for multiplayer. Server browser hits my face with lists of information. -AWP-Warfare Capture the Island mode looks appealing tonight. Played it a couple times before, and I feel comfortable with the basics by now. Server connection established.Click! I'm in, filling the boots of a digital NATO badass. Apparently, international treaty organisations occasionally require the service of men with guns. Disturbing thought, but I'm no politician. I'm just a nobody with a rifle, taking orders that filter down the food chain. Those orders fill my mind now. Objective: town. Location: nearby...as the crow flies. Heh, the team's commander does have airborne technology unlocked, I just don't have the cash to buy a lift yet. Looks like I'm taking the scenic route. A quick check of my map tells me I'm at one of our hidden frontier bases and that there's two whole mountains between me and the nearby town. Great... I'll be taking the scenic route to the scenic route. The map tells me more: several of my team members and their A.I. controlled task forces are currently approaching the town. I'm already late for the party :(Might as well bring the fireworks.The base I'm at has only an armour factory and infantry barracks, but both will well suit my rapidly forming battle plan. I'm thinking heavy calibre fire support from high ground, overlooking the town. The topographic information in the map shows that the road I'll be taking is nestled around a minor hill as it approaches the town. Perfect. I'll park two BMPs there and they'll provide overwatch of the whole area while my comrades finish their capture of the town. An LAV will ferry me and one squad of A.I. infantry to the combat zone. I spend the required funds and set the plan in action.Wait a tick, BeatYourHeadIn, are you telling me you actually have to plan how you’re going to get your troops and equipment from point A to point B in ARMA2? Logistics in a game!? Yes, actual logistics...in a game with a map so FRIGGIN’ big you need to employ logistical planning skills to see any sort of success. And it's not boring!Back to the story. Formation of a military convoy. A few orders issued to my A.I. controlled task force later and the BMPs are on point while I lounge in the command chair of the LAV at the rear of the column. I man the turret-mounted automatic grenade launcher, a devastating weapon. Its barrel is ominously pointed at and tracking a lollygagging friendly player as my convoy departs base. Yeah, that's right chump, make one wrong move and I'll end you! Though itching to test the power of my new toy, I decide it's not worth getting banned over.  I let my teammate live, for now.The A.I. drivers of my convoy are as dim as a new moon, but I can fine tune my plans and keep up with current events while they drive. It's an 10 to 15 minute (realtime) drive that negotiates a winding mountain pass through an elegant evergreen forest. These are backroads, unpaved; enemy forces unlikely to be using this route. I feel secure enough that I spend most of the trip looking at the map, reading topography, lanes of fire, positions of friendlies. I smile when I realize I could probably minimize ARMA2 and play a few rounds of Counterstrike while my convoy travels.Dying immediately is certainly the last thing I'm worried about as I crest the peak of the second mountain.Suddenly: EXPLOSION..DEAFENING SOUND..FROM BEHIND..MASSIVE DETONATION..JESUS H. CHRIST WHERE IS THAT VOLUME KNOB! What is going on here!?My turret pans to the rear of the LAV. The sight, what a sight...I'll never forget. Fire. Wall. 60? 70 feet tall? A wall. Of fire. Taller than the trees in the forest, literally FILLS my view from left to right. There is nothing in view except the fire. I'm in awe. Confused. Shaken. I've seen 'splosions in this game before, BUT NEVER LIKE THAT! Did somebody tried to nuke me FFS!? I know there's no nukes in this game mode, so...Over the cacophany of destruction: the scream of jet engines. Very close. As the flames die down, a large shape traverses the air over the crest of the crag. Airframe, Sukhoi configuration. Enemy. Wing tilted down slightly; canopy visible. I know he's surveying the carnage below him. Hunting me. Cursing his aim when he sees the LAV still intact. I feel small, molecule small; what I just witnessed was caused by his war machine. Napalm bombs. Heavy ordinance. Whatever it was, it dealt complete destruction to that forest.Understand this, readers: in this game, air superiority is a literal phrase. Air is SUPERIOR in this game. This isn't your Battlefield "oh look I can shoot a few rockets from my jet fighter and maybe kill one or two goofs on the ground and then reload (because reloading rockets on a flying jet makes a lot of sense) and kill a couple more goofs" experience. No! In ARMA your aircraft can have a payload of more than a hundred devastating rockets and you can fire 'em full auto like a machine gun and destroy an entire town worth of goofs on the ground if you wanted to. Ha! Forget about balance! This is the real life Shiznit. Modern air forces don't invest heavily in war planes because they're "balanced". They invest in them because they can kill a hell of a lot of people quickly! ARMA2 knows this. Simply put, the developers have a big Bohemian boner for air power.But BeatYourHeadIn, what happened next? Tell us! Okay, I'll tell you. A miracle happened. My convoy survives the 'splosion to end all 'splosions. My battle plans go up in smoke like the forest around me. My current objective is to live through the next 30 seconds. The LAV is the only reason I'm still alive. It is damaged, but drivable. I order my drivers to haul♥♥♥♥♥in a forwardly direction. I track the Sukhoi as the convoy labours onward. The receding bogey performs a wide highspeed U-turn. He's heading straight for me again. Relentless much? He's the UPS guy we all wished was real: the one who comes back after he missed you the first time, instead of leaving a note telling you to pick up your package at the office near the airport!Then, from beyond the first mountain I had passed: a smoke trail racing skywards. Anti-aircraft missile! Ha! RETURN TO SENDER, A-HOLE! Two vectors intersect in a puff of smoke and light. Direct hit! Booyah! Wait, uh... he's still flying at me. HEY! HE'S STILL FLYING AT ME!With black smoke billowing out of his engines, this topgun is still determined to deliver my severance package. Frantically, I order the BMPs to target the limping jet. Cannon rounds arc through the sky in attempt to smite the airborne menace. Sukhoi Dude is getting closer, but he's losing altitude. Fast. He's now descending below my level on the mountain, looking up at me through the trees as he approaches. None of the BMP fire connects, but it doesn't matter. THIS GOOSE IS COOKED BOYS! Relief. Now, his desperation salvo of rocket fire is way off-target; falls harmlessly some distance away. I watch him frantically yaw right and nose up as his fighter loses the last of its life-sustaining lift and plummets in a sideways cartwheel into the trees. The inferno he leaves behind is a feast for the eyes. There was nothing left but a dark crater.Now, I can start thinking about that town again...What, are you apes gonna dig him a grave!? We got our own mission to die for! Forward march!All that's left to say is: play this game!

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												I grab my rifle. One last day. I run to the sarge. One last fight. I board the huey and we take off to the island of chernarus.We land, and slowly crawl out and lay in the drenched bushes from the last nights rain. Our objective is to take out the target, a war lord that is helping out the OP-FOR take over the island. We move up to a shaded, half destroyed barnhouse that was obviously bombed a few days ago. We run upstairs, and sit at the side of the window so we don't get spotted out by a sniper. The quiet is too much, no distant battle noises at all, no vehicular action whatsoever. Just the sound of the metal from our rifles resting against the shattered glass window frame. "Delta-one, come in. We have spotted an enemy convoy heading to your position, possibility of the commander in one of the trucks, how copy? Over." "Good copy, over." "MEN, GO PUT YOURSELF AGAINST THOSE WINDOWS AND DEFEND THE HOUSE!" The sarge yells. I sprint over to the right side window and rest my M4 against the smashed out window. A silhouette of a tank comes over the horizon of the road. "Sarge, I see an armor coming over the horizon, over" I say. "Take cover and wait for my orders!" The sergeant barks at us. The rest of us wait for a few minutes as the sarge keeps peeking over my window, wondering how we are going to evade/take this convoy out with one M136 Rocket Launcher.The sergeant peeks over again. "The convoy has stopped infront of the house, get ready boys, I think we have been spotted!" "АК Солдат! Перейти четкое наверху!" A russian voice from downstairs yells. We all point our weapons at the stairs, and we see a shadow emitting on the wall appearing to be walking up the stairs. "Get ready" Sarge whispers. The russian soldiers head pops over the stairs, we all start shooting our rifles at him. "ВРАГ пятнистый! --- Черт!" The soldier yells, one bullet hits his head and a mist of red blood flys from his head as he drops to the ground. "Dossy, go check the window!" The sarge demands, I look out the window and see a russian soldier wielding an rpg in his hand pointing up at the window. The rpg turns into a fireball coming closer and closer, and the whole top floor is leveled by the explosion.My eyes open, to see the sarge, and the rest of the squad dead around me. My legs are broken but that doesn't stop me. I equip my rifle, load a magazine, aim through the sights and put my sights on a russian soldiers. I shoot him in the chest and he drops, still alive, he pulls out his makarov and shoots my shoulder. My hands shaky, I fire a few more bullets in his direction before manages to get a shot on my head.(Based on Multiplayer ACE Milsim I played.)

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												This Review will be the same for Operation ArrowheadPros - Actual Military Simulation- Realistic Design for both Takistan and Chernarus- Decent Singleplayer Campaigns- Great Ingame Sound Effects- Realistic Scenarios and Military Stategies- Multiplayer is very Mod-Friendly and full of options- Fleshed Out Ingame Menus to adjust pretty much everythingCons - DayZ destroyed the community (More Below)So my only real con with Arma II and Operation Arrowhead is that the community that remained on Arma II, mostly a few small Warfare and Domination Communities, is now dead and has moved on to Arma III, that is understandable. Arrowhead is a different story. The game is still very alive, the issue with Arrowhead is the community is ruined. DayZ brought around some of the worst types of people. Before DayZ Griefers were very rare, now they are everywhere and the worst part is, they hack and destory servers and get accounts banned. The game in its current online state is poor, and that is sad, very sad, especially since I remember when it wasn't like this. Arma III is shaping up to be a much better game than what we currently have in Arma II, and the community seems to be holding together, more than likely because DayZ is now a standalone game. My gripes are more personal and subject to opinion though. Both Arrowhead and Arma II are amazing Military Simulators. The Singleplayer is realistic, and top notch. Nothing but the Original Operation Flashpoint can really stand up to it.9/10 - Both great titles, but I would recommend not buying them anymore and just purchasing Arma III until maybe the DayZ fad finally dies out.

												ARMA II is the best military simulator (of the FPS genre) on the market. It follows a similar formula to that of EA's Battlefield series, but has a stronger emphasis on realism which lends itself to slower and more intricate gameplay. ARMA II requires a strong processor and a good deal of patience to play. Be sure to pick up Operation Arrowhead as well (if you aren't able to get the complete ARMA II collection), as it'll grant you the ability to play the renowned DayZ mod.

												Arma ll is the only game i know that not only let's you spawn 250+ people on the map (tanks,planes,helicopters and soldiers) but also let's you create a playable chicken, cow or any other animal with the option of making it the rank of colonel.The In-Game Editor has hours of endless fun by letting you create the scenario you want (each time you play the said scenario it is played differently every time so it will never be the same), be it massive scale wars across the whole map or just enjoying a nice boat ride along the coast.There is even a few campaigns to add to your enjoyment.Fed up of the Game Already?- Don't worry there is a whole bunch of sites that have modders working for your entertainment adding in more cars, boats, planes, and soldiers as well as AI improvements, Particle enhancements such as WarFX Blastcore. There is even a couple of realism mods that enhance the whole game also there is a World War 2 Mod so if you are a fan of Saving Private Ryan you can re-create that epic beach assualt at normady or just watch the U.S, U.K, Germany and others fight it out in the sky, on land or at sea. There is never any dead multiplayer servers either so you are not wasting your money with this game.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
												NOTE: As of May 31, 2014, all multiplayer capabilities have been removed from this game. This is the only reason I do not recommend this game. Otherwise, it is probably the best game I ever played in my life.I absolutely LOVED this game when it was in its prime. I've spent most of my hours playing Chernarus Life when it was still a thing that existed, usually on the Excyted Gaming servers (even if the admins were absolutely rеtаrdеd sometimes - fυсk you Eric). Regardless, I've played through the campaign, spent hours and hours at a time working with other players to liberate towns, outposts and encampments in Hohei Evolution Blue and Evolution Red on the Anzu's War Games servers. Eventually, after playing this game for a while, I purchased Operation: Arrowhead. The original ARMA 2 still had an enormous playerbase even though OA had been released for quite some time as well. I found myself enjoying ARMA 2 over OA any day. The fact that OA lacked Chernarus Life and replaced it with the less-good Takistan Life Revolution and Island Life was offputting for me, since those maps were less well suited for a civlian-vs-cops type scenario, whereas Chernarus was literally the perfect "Life" map.ARMA 2 was a bit clunky in the controls, but once you got them down (or simply adjusted the keybindings in the options menu) the game was such a blast to play. I probably spent about 50 hours in the mission editor alone, creating my own little missions and scenarios to play through with friends or on my own. I won't get in to the specific features of the game itself, because now that the multiplayer is gone nobody will ever be able to experience the game in its full potential again. The game is entirely dead now due to the GameSpy shutdown, which hosted ARMA 2 servers, but you can still play multiplayer in Operation Arrowhead. That being said, this game was absolutely fantastic. 10/10 from me, even though it had some bugs and a few odd things here and there, that's what made it ARMA 2. ARMA 3 doesn't come close to this game. Not only does ARMA 2 have more guns and vehicles than ARMA 3, but the mission editor is much better as well. So, for my conclusion?Don't buy this game. It would have made a great purchase any time before 2014, because the multiplayer still worked and there was a huge fanbase with a wide variety of servers and community-created addons that made the game so much better. ARMA 2 is now just a mediocre single-player campaign. For $12.99 USD (price as of August 12, 2016) this game is absolutely not worth it. I'd say it's worth about $5, but I really think that Bohemia Interactive should make it a free game since all it's used for nowadays is being able to play the DayZ mod.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												Why I bought the game: DayZ / Friends begging meWhat I liked about the game: *I would like to say the game says 9 minutes played I have played hundreds of hours on the mod, and about 20 on the ArrowHead expansion, which I did play with a friend and will be the basis of this review NOT THE MOD.* I bought it to play the DayZ mod at the time (yeah yeah dayz fanboy),  I've always been a fan of Delta Force, and Battlefield series. I mostly enjoyed this game as a Combat Flight/Tank Sim to be honest, not to say the ground combat is bad - I just really enjoy the feel of flying a Helicopter/Riding an APC into combat with 2 or 3 friends inside. It's a hardcore fps experience that will leave you extremely frustrated and laughing your head off, Hours have literally flown by playing this game and messing with the editor. Definitely a step up from CoD, or other typical FPS games, if youre looking for something more elaborate, and you have the hardware to take advantage of this games huge maps, doin't hesitate to try it, although overwhelming at first, rewarding in the end. Great modding and mature community.What I didn't like about the game: Playing with friends requires ports to be adjusted, this game is not easy to play with friends, and you should do your research before getting excited about multiplayer. This game is also hard to optimize, again do your research!Would I buy at current asking price of 12.99? Yes**Disclaimer**I would like to state all changes made by the developers of the game after this review could potentially make this entire review irrelevant. The current date of review 11/5/14.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												EDIT: I have changed key portions of this review due to fanboys freaking out over a difference of opinion. Let me clarify something; If you honestly enjoy this game despite its flaws and quirks, that is COMPLETELY fine. I'm glad you enjoy it, and I wish I did, but I simply do not. That's all it is. You're not an idiot for liking it, and I'm not an idiot for disliking it. Please, read the review, and consider it as someone else's point of view. It should not change your point of view if you enjoy this game. Thank you, and enjoy my review of Arma 2 :)I've have given this game many chances. I play it for a bit, than uninstall it, and then I reinstall it, thinking I may have missed something, seeing as a huge portion of people love this game. However, the more I try to play this game, the more I am mindblown this game is so popular. Let me elaborate a little.First off, I'm not knocking the games aesthetic appeal. It's a very good looking game for the most part. There are a few textures that look like they were made for a 90s PC mystery game, but overall, I am pretty impressed with the games looks, and how fast it runs. That's not my complaint though. That little feature right there, is the ONLY thing this game has going for it. Once you get past the looks of the game, get ready for a mind bogglingly BAD control scheme, unusable menus, and possibly the worst voice acting and music you've ever heard in a game. Let's start with the music and voice acting. Good lord are these bad. The score sounds like it's from an old 80's Segal movie. It's trying SO hard to be badass, and it falls so short. I'm not saying it's BAD music in itself, but with scenarios they play it in, like WALKING ACROSS A DECK, they've decided that blaring rock solos so loud, to the point where you can't even hear character dialogue, is appropriate. Really? Why is that an issue? The music should never drown out dialogue in a game, especially when it's ambient background music. This should only happen if the music is LITERALLY happening from something in the environment, like a concert or something. Now along with audio, lets look at voice acting. Now, not ALL of it is bad, but the majority is pretty much something out of vampire diaries. I know most marines and soldiers are normal guys who all want to have a good time as much as anyone else, and use phrases like "bro" and "dude" like anyone else, but when those phrases are used in this game... Oh my god. It legitimately sounds like that ONE kid from school that tried way too hard to fit in. They emphasize "BRO" way too much. "Tell me about that new sweet house of yours, BRO." And if you read that with a 90's surfer accent, you'd be spot on. Let's move onto menus. This SHOULD have been something simple. However, I made an online game over LAN (so no one would join) and was simply trying to get the hang of the controls. First off, just trying to make the game, was a task in itself. WHY IS THERE NO SIMPLE MODE SELECT?! Instead, we get this rediculous list of unspecified random words. 1. FIRST OF WAR. WHAT IS THAT??? Is that a mode? Is that the campaign? What is that? A little description would be nice, but no, there's nothing else. Just a huge list of things like that. So I selected a random one, and I get the campaign. That's fine in itself, but I'll get back to this later. Let's move on for now.So let's talk about controls. I have never, in my life played a game, that has the most backwards, rediculous, most roundabout way ever, to make controls for a shooter. Now, I'm no huge CoD fan at all. I've played a few, but I've never lost my crap over them or anything. They're mainly just "meh" games. But I'll tell you one thing; NEVER have I EVER complained about controls in a CoD game, or a BF game, or a Halo game, or just about ANY other shooter ever. Why change this scheme? I've looked at the controls, there's no reason to have them that way. Why can't MMB be the button for zooming with the scope? Guess what you use instead? THE "+" key! So NOW you're juggling between your mouse and your keys, and switching hands and WHY NOT JUST USE THE SAME CONTROLS THAT HAVE ALWAYS WORKED? So why not use the MMB to zoom the scope? Oh, I see why! Because it's being used to scroll the "ACTION WHEEL" so I can open a ♥♥♥♥ING door. No, you can't just click to open a door. You scroll to select the action, and THEN click to open. Mind you, this is how ANY action in the game works. If there's multiple things going on, like say, you're near a door, and a gun, and a person to talk to, you have to scroll through all this♥♥♥♥♥♥ and pick the one you want AMIDST all the action going on. So have fun juggling with your scroll wheel on your mouse, while trying not to get shot. Why isn't "F" the action key you ask? Because THAT'S being used to switch weapons! WHY NOT THE NUMBER KEYS?? BECAUSE THOSE ARE BEING USED FOR RANDOM SQUAD DIALOGUE! ... "C" is crouch, which is fine, but for SOME reason this isn't a toggled crouch. You have to hit "X" to stand, and "z" to prone. WHY? Why get rid of these instincts that have been ingrained in our brain since the first Halo game? Why change something that works perfectly well? Why not HOLD "C" for a couple of seconds to prone, and just hit it again to stand? So as the tutorial is teaching me this, and I think I'm getting the hang of it, and I continue to hear more robot people try to voice act, I finish the tutorial. Well you know how I'd selected the mission from the "create a game" menu before? Well instead of acting like a normal ♥♥♥♥ing game, and continuing to the next mission, it just repeats. WHAT? Why would I want to do that? Why not go to the next one? That's literally the most irritating and pointless system possible. This isn't Gallaga. I don't want to try and replay to get a higher score. I WANT TO PLAY THE GAME. So I try to quit the game, but hitting quit JUST RESTARTS THE ♥♥♥♥ING LEVEL. I had to ALT+TAB to minimize and then task manager that son of a ♥♥♥♥♥. Then I figured since I'm doing all this crap, might as well uninstall it! I can't recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a game that plays well. If you can see past the broken controls, bad dialouge, a mediocre score, and unworkable menus, and truly enjoy what Arma is trying to be, then go right ahead, and game on. But for me, some one who is probably overly critical, I can't enjoy, or recommend this game.

number of helpful: 39 of 60 people (65%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												I'm going to try and keep this simple and to the point. I am not much for words but I'll try to condense what I think about this game.Pros:1. Huge potential. Large seamless maps. You can drive, fly or run across km after km. Towns, roads etc.. Basically entire detailed islands.2. Great military sim taking advantage of the above. Realistic damage from small arms as well as vehicle weapons.3. Lots of realistic military vehicles and aircraft. Even boats.4. Multiplayer is fun, especially coop.5. Speaking of multiplayer, Dayz mod is something special. Very fun and you can waste hours and hours in it.6. The single player story is alright, I guess. Nothing to tell mom about.Cons:1. Bugs, glitches, more bugs. Absolutely unbearable, game breaking, punch your monitor and throw your computer out the window kind of bugs. Because you can only save 2 times per mission and the mission mught be very well broken before your first save and you won't know it until the end, which can take 1 hour or more if you take your time like me. All sorts of bugs. AI pathfinding drives your teammates vehicles off of cliffs. Mission scripts break and you can't complete the mission. You may fall through the floor and injure yourself badly or die (especially annoying in Dayz). I could write pages detailing the bugs, you get the idea.2. Second most annoying thing is the interface and the interaction system. You have to scroll through a list of actions to change your weapon, get in a vehicle or perform some other mundane function which shouldn't be that complicated. There's a key for everything and then some. It's very clunky, slow and prone to you pressing the wrong button or doing something unintended. Controling your squad mates and telling them where to go, what to attack is tedious at best.3. Clunky player movement? Even cars drive like crap and those are the easiest to control.4. Inaccurate helicopter controls. Don't even get me started, whatever you read on the net, trust me. The heli controls are bad and make no sense. I have no idea what they were thinking when they decided that the helicopter would start acting like and airplane above 50 mph. I can fly no problem in flight sims and the Battlefield series. I even fly RC in real life. This is innacurate, plain and simple.5. Devs had plenty of time to address these bugs/issues and this is a problem. What a bunch of underachievers. Their strategy is like this: For every new iteration/expansion, focus on adding more crap and complexity built on the same shoddy engine/interface and ignore all the bugs. Then collect money and develop the next uncooked iteration.Arma2:OA isn't that much better, either. The missions bugs are fewer, but everything else is the same.The bottom line: This is the kind of game you play because you know what to expect and you still want to play it because there isn't anything like it. You have to be a cult follower, or else you will hate it. The main reason you might get this is to play Dayz mod, which is great, but expect to be killed falling through floors, off ladders, killed by zombies walking through walls, etc... Definitely not for the casual gamer.

number of helpful: 17 of 21 people (81%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 6, 2016
												Arma 2 is a tactical, slow-paced military shooter that rewards commanding your squad and well-thought out strategy as opposed to the run-and-gun styles of modern day FPS. The game screams authenticity throughout its campaigns and expansions, and contains some of the nicest environments for its time. It's now a fairly dated action military sim. The campaign story felt real, but the plot itself was rather bland. Team fights were predictable, and needlessly complicated with the jarring communication system. Oh, and the dialogue was awful. Your team sounded like robots and shot like they had aim-bots (which wasn't necessarily a bad thing). I will say that the tutorials were in-depth and entertaining. They break down a game that would scare any person if they looked at the key binding section first. I will also say that the multiplayer system is just as rewarding. I commend its development team for being so open with its community that has returned the favour with brilliant total conversion mods such as DayZ and numerous RP servers. If you want a game with in-depth mechanics in a military setting, this is for you. Get the expansion too - another game in itself. Having developers that make expansions that thorough is now an unfortunate rarity. Support them with all of the monies.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Although this game has quite a learning curve, I have found it to be extremely injoyable. Before playing this, I did not realize just how open world it truly is. The single player campign is fun, if a little glitchy, the coop is easy to start up, and the editor is easlily one of the best I have ever used. The graphics are impressive, even for a game thats a couple years old. The voice acting is odd in this game. Since there are so many different siturations you could be in, the audio bits are all cut up. It sounds very disjointed and almost funny, but you will get used to it quickly. One big drawback that needs to be talked about is the AI. It is simply disgusting. Your squad will almost never do as they are told, and can die very quickly. And scipted evens rarely tigger, so lots of reloading required. The draw distances inparticular are impressive. I have only played a few minutes of the mulitplayer, and it seems that it lacks direction, and could take a while for anything to happen. DayZ is fun, however is somewhat annoying. I would not buy ArmA just for Dayz. I have only had this game for about three days, and have already put 15 hours into it. If you have the patience to learn it, please buy this game, and love it like I have.Pros:+Realism (Sometimes too realistic)+Graphics+Coop+Mod support+Map editior (But jesus is it confusing)Neutral:*Voice acting (You get used to it)Negitive:-Scipting errors (Waiting for hours for the AI to realize what they need to do)-Learning curve-AIOverall: 7/10 This game will appeal to only a select group of people. If you are on edge, probably dont get it, as you will most likely not like it. This requirers a ton of time to even begin to learn how to play it, and even then the game is broken a lot of the time. Yet somehow I found lots of enjoyment out of it. Dayz is very buggy and at this point just get the standalone if you want it so badly.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												The most realistic modern military shooter you can play today. Accurate projectile ballistics, including material penetration, ranging from small-caliber handgun bullets to hellfire missiles. Wound severity based on location and type of damage, including broken bones from falling damage. Fatigue and accurate movement speeds. Fluid viewpoints and the ability to lean (who does that anymore, right?) Artillery, airstikes, long-range bullet-drop snipes, the loud and scary snaps of bullets whizzing by, the inability to confirm a kill unless you see your enemy die, and more. If you are about realism, this is the game for you. The only issue is that this game requires a hardcore gaming PC to run. It will tax your system if you do not have tip-top hardware.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Did you fall in love with ARMA3 after purchasing it in beta dev. but then a few months later your pc took a dump and you couldn't play ARMA3 anymore? No? Mus jus be meh. Bought ARMA2 to compensate since my wittle podunk laptop couldn't handle A3, and I was not dissappointed. The point that I've come to figure out about Bohemia is that they mastered simulation gameplay early on. Yes, ARMA3 has its advantages, as any recent addition to a franchise would. Better environment designs, graphics, AI, weapons & vehicles, user editing & moding power, of course its all going to get better with each new addition; but ARMA2 easily keeps up with its predecessor.You've still got all the power given to you in A3 in terms of mission editing, and spite having smaller maps, they're still very much large enough to conduct full scale operations or drawn out sniper steak-outs. You still get physics and environment. Just buy the damn game! You won't regret it. I will still play ARMA2 after I get my new PC, in addition to ARMA3 (which you should also buy)

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This is the Mil Sim game. If you want to feel as close to a real war or shoot out as possible this is the game you want to play. The game vanilla isn't to bad but arma 2 is best with ACE or some other mods or custom missions. Once you play Arma you understand what a mil sim or tacitcal game is and what it isn't. Run forward like an idiot and you die, hide and you die, look the wrong way and you die. Very little hand holding and its wonderful. Its a game that attempts to recreate a warzone while still retaining some fun. If you buy Arma 2, pick up Operation Arrowhead with it because alot of mods like Dayz (I hate that garbage) require it or are better with it.Hooking up with a nice milsim group and you will have alot of operating fun. The only disadvantage is that Arma 3 is out so 2 is on the way out. Even with only another freind or player or two Escape Chernarus is a wonderfull mission especially with ACE.Graphics, Gameplay, its all good and intuitive. AI can be very impressive with ACE, vanilla AI can be very cumbersome and slow though but once they do react it can be quite impressive. Though there are alot of glitches here and there one thing to remember is its a mil sim, not a driving simulator or what have you.

Posted: July 28, 2014
												Isnt it awsome to snipe a Ka-52 with an M1A1? or take out an M1A2 Tusk with a Tunguska? or go 1v4 an be able to win with the moment of suprise? This game has it all, there are gamemodes and servers for all kinds of people and their play style. You can use tactical supports and teamwork, or go all out as a lonely wolf. The selection of vehicles and weaponry in this game is huge, go Troll your enemies or teammates with a Lada or go and demolish them with a T-90, Help out your team by flying an MV-22 and getting your team around the map or use an A-10 to provide Close Air support. When i was still a newbie to the game, people helped me and were friendly, altho the game looked a bit weird and difficult to me I got used to it and is now my Favourite game. I do recommend this game for people who like challanges and are patient. The game also has many downloadable content from Mods, Maps, Weapons and Vehicles to Single and Multiplayer missions, Graphics, UI and character change options. As i said, i do recommend this game, its got its weak points and glitches, but there also are those awsome moments when you snipe a jet with a T-72 or a SMAW, or get a lucky headshot on a guy gunning on a UH-1Y Venom.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												The best military simulator hands down.  Has a great moding community that is really helpful.  Arma 2 has a campaign but dont bother with it.  Terrible is being generous.  This game is all about user generated scenerios, and those that you make yourself.  Its pretty easy and there are lots of tutorials.  I made numerous games, some fun and goofy, others serious and hard with bits of story for my friends and I to play.  Even scenarios can be different each time as you have a chance to appear option.  Between the base game and the expansion (A true expanson) as well as player made items and viechles I see no reason to play arma3 and its fake made up guns and veicles.  For those of you who think dayz is garbage, I agree with you only because this game engine could not be a worse match.  The reason the zombies do not work is arma has no melee mechanic and building fighting was not a priority for the AI.  In 7 days to die the zombies will literally rip your face off.  Dont judge base aram2 and ace mod on that. Getting off topic.  The game is old enough now that even the notorius CPU hungry arma engine should be easier to manage.  Also turn off motion blur.  I forget if it is an option or if you have to delete a file.  I remember it being a pain.  You will get sick, why games insist on putting blur in that my human eye will already produce for me by looking at the screen is beyond me.  It just amplifies it to a point where we would have gone extinct if thats how our eyes work.Overall if you want to make scenarios with massive engagements, scripts, or small ones in a huge map, then yea this is really the only game out there.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												Arma 2 is by no means a game for noobs or traditional FPS shooters. It instead caters to players who want a realistic military shooter. And realistic it is. Before playing any game, the player must properly plan their course of action with their team members, or hell will break loose. This aspect of the game is extremely fun and engaging. It's when the mission actually begins, however, that the game becomes quite unsatisfactory. The gameplay is, unfortunately,  like a three legged horse trying to win a horse race while suffering with diabetes and terminal cancer. The sad reality is that the game's graphics are not up to par with the 2008 standard I'm used to, and the actual firefights are extremely unsatisfactory. The movement, strange screen bobbling, and clunky guns don't sound good, and their damage and recoil is questionable at most times.To make matters even worse, the interface is clunky and not easy to learn. Me and my friend were struggling to determine how to coordinate several missions. I'm all for a detailed interface, but make the options relevant in the game. Movement is even worse, and feels sadly completely broken. There are also a handful of glitches that I encountered such as falling through maps and colliding with enemy units and not being able to separate again. The AI suffers from strange glitches as well, and don't respond well to the terrain.The worst part of the game is the voice acting. Oh god... it sounds like they hired Joe at the bakery to do the voice acting, and it really shows. I have always been a stern believer in that voice acting should only be done if you have qualified voice actors who can do that job. If not, just having text is NOT a bad thing at all. Overall, Arma 2 is not the realistic military shooter that you should choose. The only realistic thing you will find here is a damaged keyboard from anger issues. If it is a realistic military shooter that you seek, then Arma 3 should be your choice as they fixed almost all the items I have mentioned above.Score: 3/10

TL; DR Version: This is as close as you get to a real modern warfare combat simulation, you get powerpoints, military jargon, and one of the worst optimized games of all time.The game opens up with a powerpoint briefing . . . reminds me of my time in Afghanistan.  Although I have heard much praise for the game I could never even get the base game to work correctly in co-op LAN.  Also the game runs slow as crap even on strong machines with dual GTX 560s.  I find the game overall to be a little too realistic if you are an actual Soldier (or have been in) in real life.  Rainbow Six, Ghost Recon, and SWAT are all games that are pseudo-realistic and have both working multiplayer and fast-paced action that can be jumped into relatively quickly.  I would recommend those before Arma II.

number of helpful: 15 of 28 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												Oh Arma 2. Where do I begin? First off, let it be known that this game is NOT a 1st/3rd person shooter game, it's tagged a "Military Simulator" or "MilSim", for short, for obvious reasons. This game is designed to deliver a realistic warfare feel to it, complete with accurate ballistics, realistic gear loadouts, and over 40 weapons and vehicles. I paid for this game and all the expansions, forking out a pretty 40$, mainly for the DayZ mod, as Arma 2 and Operation Arrowhead are required, the other expansions supposed to "improve graphics/animations", so after it sitting in my library for a couple years I felt inclined to try it. With that out of the way, time for the nitty gritty of this review.The game spans over many miles (yes, literally MILES) of open country to explore throughout missions, including many cities, villages, farms, industrial complexes, hidden camps and castles, and the general rolling fields and foothills. Although, alot of this is just more "eyecandy/backdrop" than actual relevant terrain, as some of the missions only have you operating within specific areas. No worries, as when the missions open up for you, you are allowed to decide exactly how, when, and where you go about meeting and accomplishing your objectives. So, putting you in the boots of an experienced First Recon Marine Combat Vet, and allowing you to control his squad, drive Humvee's, or call in Helo-Extract at your leisure sounds tempting, correct? This is where the game is wrong. Firstly, if you've docked many hours in Call Of Duty, or Battlefield even, and for some reason think this game is gonna be along those same lines, then you're wrong. It's nothing like them. In more bad ways than good, I'm afraid. A vast majority of the voice acting is horrendous, im saying Marine's that havent hit puberty horrendous. Or how important character's voice over sounds like it was done over a phonecall, perhaps google translate even, and any character that is not in your squad has terrible or non-existant animations, standing like statues only moving their mouths to the occasional garble the spit up. Top it off with even worse AI and you got yourself a nice♥♥♥♥♥♥garbage cake. Try this, order your squad to pile into a Humvee, then order them to drive to a specific location, for me it was literally up the road 1/4 mile, in a straight line. Now proceed to witness them drive into anything and everything that was not in that straight line. Im talking hitting walls, buildings and other vehicles, while tring to backup continuously into the brick wall behind us, despite a simple order to move "forward". Ok then, them driving is a no go, let us try the Helo. Some missions allow support vehicles, such as Helo transport. Call it in, it flies to your position, you pick a drop off point, it flies there. No problem. Right? Wrong, again. In the middle of clearings, I've had the chopper refuse to land to get me and my squad, I've had it crash trying to take off, or drop us off, I've even had one of my squadmates run into the rear propellar and die instantly, when all I told him to do was get in. So far, so good I suppose. However, if you find yourself more perserverant than I, and want to continue to play this game, some advice should help; -Get used to not firing your gun throughout an entire mission. Only having 5 mags may seem daunting at first, but once you realize your squad is going to most likely see the enemy before you do, they're gonna shoot them (or try to at least) first. -Battlefield veterans can recall experiences when getting sniped from across the map was frustrating, but you'd just wait for a buddy in a chopper to rain down hot 5mm hell on them. For this game, imagine every damn enemy is a sniper. Most engagements for me and my squad involve us firing at enemy "positions", meaning "where we think they are", at an average of 150-300 meters away, or just shy of 1000 feet away. Thats about 10 football fields in distance. - game deletes your saves upon completion of a mission, meaning if it didnt quite go according to plan, which is alot of this game is planning, have fun restarting the mission. --PROS---Good graphics-4 expansions-plenty of weapons/vehicles-weapon ballistics is fun to play with--CONS---Terrible AI-Game saves deleted when mission ends-Horrendous voice acting (literally can't stress this enough, although kind of remedied from expansions)-Character animations are stiff, and poor overall. -perhaps too many controlls, not for everyone.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
												The most realistic modern military shooter you can play today. Accurate projectile ballistics, including material penetration, ranging from small-caliber handgun bullets to hellfire missiles. Wound severity based on location and type of damage, including broken bones from falling damage. Fatigue and accurate movement speeds. Fluid viewpoints and the ability to lean (who does that anymore, right?) Artillery, airstikes, long-range bullet-drop snipes, the loud and scary snaps of bullets whizzing by, the inability to confirm a kill unless you see your enemy die, and more. If you are about realism, this is the game for you8.7/10

content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												still a sweet game, and cranked up still looks awesome (your pc still might not be able to handle it up all the way).theres still tons of people that play this online, and there are mods out that took years and years to produce.  If you dont like one style of gameplay there are several other types that are completely different and have their own independant followings and a very robust community overall despite this game having been out for years already.  Your probably already aware there are several spinoff games that have been made after mods, and many people still prefer the original versions and still play them.Personally right now i am going back with realism and sound effects mods (ace), a ai upgrade (asr), and some graphic upgrades (blastcore) and the game becomes a thing of beauty even just the normal campaign and i wish i had started off with some of these mods to begin with.  (if your just getting started id recommend a mod manager and download program called playwithsix).at this point id probably recommend getting combined ops as opposed to just vanilla, as the expansion is completely worth it in its own right.

												This game is excellent. It possesses a good game-play, albeit one that can be stiff at times but the sheer amount of customizability and flexibility of the game greatly offset this. The graphics can be rich an vibrant if you have a computer to support it. Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a more realistic military shooter with some strategy and tact involved in the game-play, especially someone who enjoys looking at situations creatively.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												I'm clearly missing something with this game. I got to the free roam part and just quit. The map is so open that you have to use your pilot to travel from place to place, which in theory is cool, but just doesn't work. The pilot, Maddox, is a complete idiot and crashes his helicopter whenever i call on him, so he is unusable. Also, you die after getting shot twice, even on easy mode, and your useless teammates won't revive you and die just as easily. This game would serve better as an actual combat simulation instead of a retail game. Multiplayer isn't any better due to the stupid amount of hackers. Clearly people love this game, so i must reiterate: i'm missing something.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												Now I really like this game. It's fun to play with friends, is a good challenge, and is generally really fun. You can buy a Hummer, appoint your trusted friend as the cunning witty gunner, you can go on a nice roadtrip to the objective, and then watch as everyone you have in your car is shot to bits, as you're trembling behind the stering wheel, cowering for life. NExt thing you know, you're miles behind enemy lines, trying not to take an enemies gun where the sun doesn't shine. Then your cunning witty gunner is also a cunning witty pilot.... ok nevermind, he's dead now, but ♥♥♥♥ it. It's a lot of fun to play.but the community is sogoddamnSTIFFThe amount of times i've heard the words "you'd be court marshalled for that" is more than I can remember! Albeit I can fix that with a poof of the ol' pistol, but it's just so annoying! HAVE SOME FUN! Wait... I see it now... back in trench warfare, soldiers stuck their helmets up with a stick to see if there are any enemies to shoot at them. This is the same thing! They hold the stiffs up with a stick up their asses to see if there are enemies! ARMA YOU ARE FABULOUS!

Posted: May 14, 2011
												This is a terrible branch of Operation Flashpoint. It's touted as super-realistic, which I'm sure it is, but that doesn't equate to smooth gameplay or a fun experience for the player. If you want to play a military sim, and can deal with a clunky, dated interface, then you might like ARMA II. I wanted to give it a chance, but it reminds me of OFP (which is a good thing) but still has all the shortcomings I could do without.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												At first, I bought this game on sale as a ten dollar day-z machine. I wasn't too sure how to run day-z, so I started up Arma 2 and decided to try this game out. It had a certain charm, that reminded me of Lone Survivor. In turn, I just started up the campaign and ended up beating it. I think that this game was certainly helpful when I finally playd DayZ because I learned many of the unique combat skills of Arma 2. My only complaint is that nobody ever gets a chance to play this game. Most people will buy this, and go play DayZ. Personally I would recommend this game to anybody who wants an actually realistic FPS game. Overall, it is probably one of my favorite games of the genre.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												Yes, I do recommend this game - but you need to know what you're getting into."Arma 2" is a serious simulation, not a "shooter." It's complex, and brutally unforgiving. Make a mistake, even a small one, and you will take the one or two bullets necessary to die. You will be fired at - very effectively - by enemies you can't see. You are probably not going to be casually taking down armored vehicles and helicopters while dismounted. The TUTORIAL can curbstomp you with vicious efficiency.Let me put it like this. "S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow Of Chernobyl" is a cakewalk compared to this title.But the game (if you can call it that) is beautiful. That is, it's beautifully crafted, with oceans of effort apparently invested in it being authentic. That authenticity - or what appears to be authenticity to a layman like me - is what makes the experience so lethal.And engaging.I barely scratched the surface of the game's content, even after putting in over 20 hours. I ended up quitting because I couldn't manage the difficulty curve, but my total experience was one of being very impressed. There's a lot to do, and a lot of freedom.I do dispute a review that says the game rewards patience. Sometimes it does, and sometimes it punishes your patience with devastating force. Then it punishes your impatience. Then it punishes your patience again. That's not a flaw. That's the nature of simulating war.The flaws that I did find were mostly related to AI and event triggers. Sometimes, what I thought would happen after issuing a certain order or carrying out a certain task is not what ended up happening. I also found the "command" interface to be rather strange. I made it work a fair bit, but I never really got the hang of it.Even so, I feel that this piece of software is a masterwork, and worth experiencing if you want to try something different...and something so difficult that "Nintendo Hard" doesn't even begin to describe the ride.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
												I love realistic games. I like strategizing, on-the-fly planning, and high stakes. If you've ever played the classic Rainbow Six series, you'll understand. But this game is not like that.This game is about getting shot through the damn trees and bleeding to death on the cold hard ground, never seeing your enemy. Realistic? Yes. Fun? No, but because the vectors of the tree impede your view, and put you at an impossible disadvantage. Didn't press the right radio response? Don't worry, the freken chopper will leave you stranded and you'll waste a couple of hours trying to figure out how to end the stupid 3hr mission where you shot no one and did nothing, only to discover the end-sequence error is now causing you to restart the whole stupid pointless operation.So yeah, it is pretty realistic. But not in a good way.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												Okay, so maybe in the future I'll write a game for Operation Arrowhead but for now this is a review on Arma 2. Honestly, don't buy this game. This is a great game with dozens of hours to play and a lot of *fun* hours, something a lot of games don't do. There are an unbelievable amount of choices in singleplayer gameplay this game has, and all are really enjoyable. LOOK AT LAST PARAGRAPH FOR WHY TO NOT BUY IT.For Arma 2's campaign, it isn't amazing, but it can be pretty fun. I really think the RPG elements they added were pretty cool, especially making this game's campaign less linear and more about random events, since that gives this game a lot of replayablility, along with like 4 different endings. The more short-term missions felt like a good scenario, but sometimes the long missions drag on a lot, adding unnecessary hours of just driving that isn't really fun. A good example is the mission "Razor Two", an unbelievably boring missions that takes like 3 extra hours (without a walkthrough) to get every piece of evidence and do everything. Too many of these missions have the evidence thing, and it's definitely rewarding at the end game, but when I realized what it did, I was really, really disappointed. It plays it out to be a huge thing that really affects the game, because I mean, collecting evidence of terrible war-crimes is a pretty big deal; unfortunately, it literally just gives you strong reinforcements so the last mission is easier, and that really made me feel like spending maybe an extra 5 hours on the campaign (and this campaign is short, the campaign is probably 15 hours if you don't search for evidence). Overall, this campaign isn't bad, but I don't think I'd recommend getting the game for it; it just isn't memorable.Scenarios are an entirely different story. These are pretty fun, and there are a lot of them (I think 7 of them). They are essentially a short term burst of action and fun while including some decisions that aren't necessarily long term, but rewarding. They all vary in gameplay a good amount too, giving lots of choices for gameplay style and pace. There are even some that feel like a one-man first person RTS, which is really interesting, especially since it still maintains the feeling of a sim. Overall, I strongly recommend at least trying every scenario, they are really well made and fun to play, and just feel good.Armory and Editor are shorter in descriptions, but much more in content than Scenarios and the Harvest Red Campaign so I'll group them together. The interesting thing about Armory is it really feels more like just a thing to mess around with, experiment, and get a feel for the weapons, but it can be much more than that. There are little side missiosn that you get to do that put your weapon into actual realistic situations so you can imagine its usefulness on the battlefield, which is a pretty neat thing to add. I don't personally like editor, but for anyone who has fun making levels, this is really well done. It's pretty simple to use, and it doesn't take too long to make a detailed, fun, and good mission to try yourself. Also, you can download other people's missions to judge them yourself, which can be really fun. While I don't think these are as good as the main stuff for singleplayer, but these are just fun little things to tinker with while you're bored.This doesn't really sound like I dislike this game, and I don't, I think it's amazing, but it isn't worth buying, which is really unfortunate. It really comes down to the fact that Operation Arrowhead has every single thing that I described and like 50 more hours for just singleplayer. Really, you shouldn't be buying this if you think this game looks cool, and should instead buy OA instead. This game had multiplayer removed recently (which is a huge problem, the multiplayer for this game is a lot of fun) and Operation Arrowhead actually gives not only another campaign, 7 more scenarios, and great multiplayer, it gives $8 DLCs with campaigns, scenarios, weapons, factions, and vehicles which are a ton of fun. So if you really want this game, buy OA and you'll experience what's so great about this series without spending money you didn't need to spend.

number of helpful: 5 of 11 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												The Basics: Military shooter with a focus on realismPrevious Time Spent: 46 minutesExpectation of learning Curve: HighWhy I bought this: The infamous Day-Z mod + a steam saleMy 3 Hours with the Game: After checking to see if any multiplayer servers were active, and finding them dead, I resigned myself to single player. I began with an intro scenario in which my compatriots and I were helicoptered in to an active battle zone, with the goal of moving about, shooting people, and holding territory. I played several other scenarios, and never gave the game the amount of effort or care needed to master it. First Impressions: This is a frightening game that alternates between somewhat boring movement, and extremely dangerous combat. Combat feels quite realistically dangerous, without any sort of health bar, or clear explanation of how injuries work. In my first firefight, I got lucky for a bit before taking a shot, and being brought down. I didn't die however, and spent some time waiting for first aid before returning to the fight. In other fights, I seemed to take injuries that caused me to bleed (at a hard to discern rate), die instantly, or be knocked down, presumably wounded. Not taking cover, or generally acting like an action hero/video game character were recipes for disaster and death. Additionally, combat tended to take place at such a long distance that it was difficult to tell where the enemy was firing from. My highlight: I eventually realized that the map covered an area much larger than my immediate combat zone, and in one of the missions decided to steal a pickup truck and leave. This actually worked, and I managed to make my way out of the combat zone (after taking a little bit of fire, resulting in a broken window). I followed the main dirt road out of the village we were supposed to be sweeping, and found myself in another village. This, and all subsequent villages were devoid of life, presumably ghost-towns fled due to the war I was taking part in. I drove some 3 km through farm villages before hitting a paved main road. From there, I drove through woods and mountains to the coast (stopping to swim in a pond). From the coast, I swam out to a small island and decided to end my 3 hour run as the unofficial lighthouse keeper of this empty country. My verdict: This game works really well at what it's trying to do, but that isn't exactly to my taste. So, I do not regret picking it up, but I can't see myself playing beyond 3 hours. Next time I'll be covering the Day-Z mod.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Arma II is good in many aspects. It is very realistic and for some can immerse you in gameplay. However it is only playable if you are willing to learn all of the commands. Many of the controls are not shown on the control page, and only appear on the tutorials once or twice that cannot be brought back up. There are so many different commands it is impossible to do anything. Instead of being able to start the tutorial, play through them once and then go right into the campaign, you need to learn the different commands for six or seven different game features that do not correlate. Driving was easy enough, but commanding tanks was confusing and flying a helecopter was impossible. Many games for PC use a minimal amount of buttons, reuse them for different mechanics, and use combinations. Arma II uses every key on the keyboard with minimal combinations and confusing menus.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												Bought it for the DayZ mod, love it for the DayZ mod, the DayZ mod gets a thumbs up from me. Otherwise it's just too control complex to be fun, especially (plane) flight. The beauty of a PC game vs a console game (among a long list of things) is that controls don't have to be limited to roughly 12 buttons. But seriously.... you dont need to use all 116 keys and every part of the mouse for EACH control scheme (infantry, land vehicle, helicopter, multiple types of aircraft etc.) It's near impossible to fly without a joystick. imagine, if you will, the following: A + D = roll... Yep got it. W + S = pitch ...so far so good =)... now add Q + Z = trottle up and down... ok so it's hard to bank left and use throttle, I can handle that... but wait there's more! X + C = Yaw.. so now that you're trying to make fine adjustments to properly lead and strafe you need to completely forget you're throttle because you're trying to maintain your bank to match your're adversary. but wait... turning too hard makes you loose velocity.... so stop tuning with yaw, correct speed. return to yaw. But wait there's more! F = to select your weapons, which aren't quite clear what they even are at first, until you accidentally fire one of the 2 only missles, 2 bombs, or 300 bullets you have (which you can empty in 4-5 seconds.) But wait! There's more! While you're trying to simply stay away from the ground and fumble in utter dumbfoundedness with you're weapons while trying to hit a peanut sized target with next to no ammo remaining, you moved you're mouse! Oops it controls pitch and roll too, at the same time as the keyboard! While trying to grasp all this at once you realise your landing gear is still down.... ok so now it's off the the scroll wheel menu (which is actually quite alien at first) to retract it. Now you're distracted for a few seconds from the incoming ground with your upside down aircraft seemingly resisting all your movements by about 25%. So on top of all this you now need to compensate for the resistance to your movement. Oh and remember to close/retract/lower your flaps. Whatever term the game uses is useless because you're scroll menu offers "flaps up" or 'flaps down". Am i lowering them from the top of the aircraft to close them? Or was it bring the flaps from the bottom up to retract them... Oh hey, there's a note on the top right of the screen, something about using TAB to acquire targets... Wait... there were instructions there.... that's ok I'll restart again.... *reading* Welcome to the tuto... *switch* times up! new message! In this excercise we will be going to *switch*. There is litterally a 5 line message that is on screen for less than a second. Did I mention this is only the boot camp? Now lets clear something up. I LOVE complex games. From ROTK to Total War to Crusader Kings II to Europa Univeralis. I enjoy a steep learning curve because the time invested usually nets a fantastic game that not every moron can just jump on to "pWn HiS n0oBzoRs" or whatever it is they do. I have over 14 hours of play simply in the tutorials. I have nearly given up on the main game. But I'm a stubborn type that will keep doing it till it's done. But most people will have given up ages ago, which is a bit of a shame. The game has a fantastic engine overall and is almost unerringly realistic. If the tutorial gets a very extensive tune-up I could see many more positive reviews. But too many people are kicked flat in the teeth with this (fun but) incredibly newbie unfriendly game. Ending on a positive note thought, glitches have been non-existant to me. So I don't know if I'm just missing them out of sheer dumb luck or they have been fixed by now.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												When I first got ARMA2, I went for the complete edition because I wanted to play DayZ Mod. The best deal I could get at the time was $20 for everything, which seemed like a steal. However, It didn't run well on my computer at the time. Since getting a faster computer that could handle it, and playing ARMA2 itself fluidly, I realize that it's still not a terribly fun game. Keep in mind, it is first and foremost a Military Sim. That doesn't mean that, when it comes down to combat, the gunplay isn't well done. It is! It's difficult yet satisfying to actually make a kill. However, the game still doesn't feel well pollished. Even though the controls are supposed to feel more real than FPS-ey, they work exceedingly slowly. It just makes for a bore. And when I finally got DayZ up and running, it just keeps crashing on me.If I had to suggest what to do, I'd say get the game DayZ, and if you really want a military sim, get ARMA3. It supposedly has fixed many of the glitches that this game has, as well as having extended content. This game ain't worth $20, even for each DLC and the free DayZ mod. It's worth your money to skip this and get better games. Sorry.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												This might not be your game if the only fps' you play start with "battlefield" or "call," unless you only play on hardcore modes. If you like military sims, then this is the quintessential experience. You can devote endless hours playing this game with nearly endless options. BI supports it's modding community and it is very expansive. They also occassionally have cash prizes for mods. Unfortunately the modding community isn't well represented in steam workshop, but downloading mods from BI's forums isn't difficult. There are some intuitive control issues with the UI, but it's forgivable. I wish I had more time to give this game so I could join a group that plays regularly, like ShackTac.As of right now A2 has more mods and a bigger crowd playing it due to the mods, in comparison to A3.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2014
												It's okay.  I don't enjoy playing with random people so I only do so with those I know. We tried this and while it looks good, we just felt it was wrong for us.  There were times we just felt it was too difficult for two people to enjoy by themselves.  We appreciated the realism but it was clear to us that this wasn't for us. I'm not saying it's a bad game at all. I am just saying if you just want a military shooter that you can enjoy solo or co-op with one friend, then this might not be something you'd enjoy.  So for those I cannot recommend this game.If you're looking for a more realistic game than say...Battlefield, this might be something for you.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												ARMA II is a very realistic MilSim Game for the pc. You have a choice of playing Single Player or Multiplayer. In Single Player not only can you play Campaign, but you can also test Vehicles, Weapons, Creatures,  and more. The teams are BluFor, OpFor, Independent, and Civilian. You can also play as one of those four teams in Armory. Also in Armory you can be assigned challenges. The challenges are, Steal The Item, Assasination, Taxi, Shooting Range, Kill House, and more. All and all this is a really fun game.

But you couldn’t, you didn’t, and now you’re paying the price, you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ idiot. I will♥♥♥♥♥♥fury all over you and you will drown in it. You’re ♥♥♥♥ing dead, kiddo.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2013
												OK I may have done a review earlier, but I didn't give it the credit it deserves. It's hard to put it in words. The campaign is alright, and the scenarios are fun, but the multiplayer is what it must be like in real combat. It's not this Call of Duty♥♥♥♥♥♥ it's watching planes scream over head and hearing tanks rolling by, not knowing where the enemy will be next. But the build your own mission, it's like coordinating an army, then fighting along side them. You feel a certain pride you get no where else as an A10 Warthog screams over head, dropping bombs on a target you marked. Or capturing an airfield with just you and your buddy. Pros-Petty OKRealistic gunplayRealistic combatFunCons-Clunky animationsbad Voice ActingNeed a beastly PCSeriously, it's like Skyrim and Battlefield 3 combined. Can't even wait to see how friggin awesome Arma III is gonna be. Guys. Buy this. Or Arma 3Seriously, I can't even describe the feeling this game gives you. Remember, BUILD YOUR OWN MISSION. It's much more fun. And more badass. Link to a tutorial-http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=plzPQ5qfXWcWatch all the parts and youll figure it out. BUY THE GAME. ITS AMAZING!!!!

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												I originally made this review when it was easy to play. Now it's different. My opinion hasn't changed about the play style, but a more important thing that this game is based around. If you're looking for a tactical military shooter involving Russia and the United States, you've come to the right place.Pros:+Authentic Vehicles and Weapons+Tactical+Multi-player+Good Community+SingleplayerCons:-Most Multiplayer Servers shut down when GameSpy shut down (So it's difficult to get into a server)-Some hackers and cheaters (like every game)-Bugs/GlitchesThere's not much else that I can remember about this game, because I haven't played in so long after the GameSpy shut down. I remember that the servers aren't as good as they used to be, there isn't as many gamemodes. If I can remember, the one remenence of Arma 2 in the game is the singleplayer and the DayZ type servers that are still standing. The game is practically dead, but it's still is a fun game based off of what it was like. If I were you, get the current Arma. It has what Arma 2 had, and more!

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												ArmA II is the most realistic military shooter when it wants to be. Unless you go onto some super professinal server where everyone is shouting orders into their mics, this game will end up being more silly then real. The in-game editor is where it all happens. While some people will waste months making super-realistic missions that are so detailed you'd think the devs made it, most others like myself just ♥♥♥♥ around in the editor. Spawn 100+ F-15's and hop into one. Spawn 100+ C-130's and watch them all crash into each other. Spawn as a cow. Spawn 200 soldiers. 100 US, 100 RU. Now, this game has intense detail and a HUGE map, so unless your machine is fairly good, you'll have a very laggy time. Their are countless things you can do to the files to make your game run faster, I mean, my "Machine" is a 2010 Toshiba laptop for Christ's sake and I can run it at about 35-45 FPS.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												ARMA 2 depicts real militry gear very accurately.Arma 2's command menu is partially hidden, and won't initially display all options as in ARMA CWA / OFP and ARMA 1 / Armed Assault. AI in ARMA 2 have trouble deciding on stance and maintaining formation, often running out in front of a player like Left4Dead AI teammates. In addition to isuing commands, the player can switch between units similar to Rainbow Six or Ghost Recon. Single player can be frustrating because of the bad AI, so if you want a better single player experience get ARMA Cold War Assault or ARMA 3.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												Here's what I'll say, my negative feelings towards this game are mainly based on personal preferrence.Now, many, and I'd even argue most, players buy this game for the DayZ mod. If you're going to buy it, try to watch a few let's plays beforehand and learn how the game works. Otherwise, you might wind up like me.In my opinion, I really don't like this game. The interface is terrible, the game responds really slowly, the controls are bad, and it's impossible to get into. Above all that, the engine is complete crap. I don't know how to put it any other way than, "Playing this game feels like trying to steer a boat through molasses."It's not that it runs poorly on my computer, either. It just feels slow and clunky, and that's why I find this game nearly unplayable. I had a few laughs in it's DayZ mod, but the thrill wears off quickly as you find that the same problems plaguing the base game are even worse in DayZ.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding cheese cake recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients: 1 cup digestive plain sweet biscuit crumbs3 tablespoons sugar3 tablespoons melted butter40 ounces softened cream cheese1 cup sugar3 tablespoons flour1 tablespoon vanilla1 cup sour cream4 eggsDirections:For The base:.If you're using a dark pan, preheat the oven to 350. If you are using a shiny pan, 375.Combine the crumbs, melted butter and 3 tbsp sugar well and pat onto the bottom of a 9 inch springform pan. I also like to very very lightly butter the sides of the pan so that the cheesecake will not stick later on.Bake for 10 mins in your preheated oven and remove. Let it cool while you prepare your batter.For the batter:.Make sure everything is at room temperature.Combine sugar, cheese, flour and vanilla in a big bowl and mix on medium speed till well combined. Don't forget to scrape the bowl as you're doing this.Mix in the sour cream till its incorporated well. Then, add the eggs one by one, mixing well after each addition.Pour the batter into the springform and let it bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes After the baking time, turn off the oven and leave the door ajar. Let the cake cool in there for about 1 1/2 hours.Remove the cake and let it cool thoroughly. Refrigerate overnight.Release the sides of the springform.Eat.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												ARMA II is for those individuals who are unable to join the military due to their lack of physical fitness or their attraction for the genitals of someone of the same gender as them. With it's clunky, overly complex controls, ARMA II might as well ship in-packaging with a Moog synthesizer to even begin to appreciate the sub-par gameplay experience this "simulator" has to offer. To a certain extent, I can understand the appeal to hyper-realistic first person shooters, though, when you're required to hold your character's hand through the entire experience of firing his rifle, you might as well assist him in rubbing peanut butter on his testicles and beckoning his dog into the room with him. Then assisting him to pat the dog on it's head whilst you reassure him that his wife will never find out, and the dog won't remember.If you love reading maps, playing typing games, or even cleaning your bathroom, GI Joe Simulator 2009 is the game for you. Otherwise, I recommend torrenting Duke Nuke 'Em: Forever, installing it, and then uninstalling it, whilst you think of something better to waste your time on.
